intro.p: A new study examined the effect of taking micronutrients for children with ADHD. Researchers enrolled 576 children ages {{age}} years who had been diagnosed with ADHD. The children were randomly enrolled into one of two groups, a group that received a micronutrient supplement (taken as 9 to 12 capsules per day with food) and a placebo group. Clinicians, who did {{blinding}} who was receiving the supplement and who was receiving the placebo, rated the children on a range of behavioral scales both through direct observation and through interviews with parents. Additionally, the amount of time the children could spend on a task requiring focus was measured before and after receiving the treatment or the placebo. The Clinicians rated the children on a scale of “No Improvement”, “Mild Improvement”, “Moderate Improvement”, “Substantial Improvement”, “Very Substantial Improvement”. The group receiving the supplement showed a statistically significant improvement in behavior on the direct observation reports as compared to the placebo group.
